text: Missouri has a team in charge of helping workers who are out of a job due to a business closing.
speaker: SPEAKER_09

text: Tim Dunville leads that team, and he explains to Elisa Nelson the Warren Act.
speaker: SPEAKER_09

text: We call it the Warren.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You know, everything is, you know, abbreviated.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So it is the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, and it's a federal law.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: requires employers to provide a 60-day notice to their employees, you know, and local officials and to the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And the purpose of this law is to provide workers and their families with time to prepare for, like, significant workforce changes.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So there's some little caveats there that, you know, the Warren Act applies to employers with 100
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: or more employees, excluding part-time.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So if you don't have 100 employees, a warrant is not necessary, but you could still file one if you'd like, just to give 60 days notice to the employees.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Is there a loophole or something?
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: I mean, I've seen businesses put up war notices after the fact is when I sometimes see them go on your website.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: So I guess my question is, do businesses follow this law?
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: It all depends upon what some of their corporate attorneys and how they interpret the law.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Ideally, in an ideal situation, if they're going to be, we call it ethical offboarding, if they would
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: give the 60 days notice so it gives us time to make, you know, and that's all they have to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: All an employer has to do is send them the warrant notice.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And so, and this is kind of where the rapid response comes in, where once we get a warrant notice, we have 24 hours to contact that employer.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And what we try to do, our main goal is to talk to that employer, have us come in and talk to those employees.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You know, it gives us the 60 days and we can get in there and help understand, help those workers understand what's going on and how, you know, the state is.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And the job centers are there to help them in a transition from losing their job to finding other employment.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Because as we know, the bills don't stop coming.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You basically try to drive them to these job centers that we have around the state to see what opportunities are out there for them just out there in the workforce then.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: Yes.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So if an employer lets us come in and
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Because also, if an employer is closing, we want them to keep the workers as long as that business is going to stay open.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And we really stress the importance of the workers to stay to the very last day.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So they give the 60-day notice and they're going to close on that 60th day.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Those workers will be eligible for certain programs because they are dislocated workers.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So they're affected workers because they lost their jobs due to no fault of their own.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So when that happens, then they're
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: eligible through the WIOA program for education, training, on-the-job training, and other programs.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So it's very important that if a company is going to do close, they send out the warrant notice, it's very important for those employees to stay to that very last day.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Because if they leave before then, they're not a dislocated worker anymore.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: They left on their own.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And then they may not be eligible for those programs.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Do Missouri businesses know that you have this team that is able to go in and do this?
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: Or is this a part of really what we're trying to do is raise awareness?
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So it's every state has a team like this.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So it's a federally funded and fairly mandated that every state has a rapid response team.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So besides the dealing with rapid response, we go out and talk to employers and
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And to get them into our MoJob system, so if those employers are looking for workers, you know, it's part of the public workforce system.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And that way, we're job seekers that are looking for jobs.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: They can match with the employers that we have in there.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So we're always going out promoting jobs.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: The programs are offered through workforce development and through the job centers.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So the rapid response just happens to be one of the other duties that we have.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And like I said, it's a federally mandated program and every state has one rapid response team.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Can you talk a little bit about what the worker displacement situation currently looks like in Missouri?
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: As far as it seems like most of the closures, war notices are coming from more so the eastern side of the state, whether it's the northeast down to St.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Louis and down to down the southeast part of the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So it seems like the team on the eastern side of the state, they've been doing a lot of rapid response events.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And, you know, again, I know we I know we briefly talked about the Warren Warren Act about.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: having 100 employees or more, but if a company has less than 100, whether it's 90 to 50, 25,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: We'll still, we would be more than happy to come out and talk to those businesses that are closing or having to lay off to go talk to those employees to let them know what's available to them, you know, through the Missouri Job Center and through OWD, you know, because they could be, like I said, they'd be eligible for education or on-the-job training.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So we just want to make this known that it doesn't have to be, a warrant notice has to be issued to any size company or business that is eligible
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Unfortunately, closing, we'll go and talk to those workers.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So Missouri has a rapid response employee transition team.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: It's in charge of helping Missouri workers who are out of a job due to a business closing.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: And Tim Dunville is in charge of the team.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: So let's say there maybe isn't...
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: a a business um who notifies you but there's someone out of a job due to a a business closure how can they um what would you suggest to them if they're interested in getting your help
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: If a business did close and no rapid response was done, if a worker comes into the job center, if they have something from that employer saying they've lost their job on a certain date, that should help them establish that they are a dislocated worker, which could be eligible for the programs that are available to dislocated workers through WIOA.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You know, you talk about some of the things that you can offer, education, on-the-job training, that kind of stuff, to workers who stay until the last day.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: So this might be more of an FAQ here.
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: Just if you have people who reach out wanting to know what you do and do not do, what does your team not do to help these workers just to make sure that they know what you do and do not do?
speaker: SPEAKER_15

text: But what we do is we also offer resume writing workshop.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: We offer workshops.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Like some of the rep responsiveness we went to, we've gone to.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Some people worked at that same company for 25 years or longer.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And they haven't needed a resume, so we'll have resume workshops at the job center.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Also, kind of the same situation, they haven't been on a job interview in quite a while.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: We will help them with interview workshops, you know, career counseling, and also job search.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You know, they...
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: When we do a rep response event, we get them entered into our system.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And when they go to the job center to discuss more options, some of those options, they'll be already started their enrollment into the MoJobs.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And we could do job searching with them.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So when an employer comes, again, this is part of what the team does.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: When we go talk to employers and get employers into our system,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: comes in and dislocated where it comes in.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: We prepare the resume and we can do candidate matching.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It takes some of the keywords from that job seeker's resume and the job description from the employer and it matches and it'll send something to the employer, say, we might have a candidate for you.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So we have that option when you go to the job center, when you bring your resume and we build your resume in our MoJob system, it can do all the candidate matching.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And again, it also helps
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: with a virtual recruiter that we have in our system for employers that are looking for workers.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: That's Tim Dunville with the Missouri Department of Higher Education and Workforce Development, Rapid Response Employee Transition Team.

text: Back on Show Me Today, Greene County Clerk Shane Scholler received the Republican nomination for Secretary of State back in 2012.
speaker: SPEAKER_09

text: He joins Marshall Griffin to share why he believes he can recapture the nomination and become our next Secretary of State.
speaker: SPEAKER_09

text: First off, if you are elected, what are your plans for the Secretary of State's office?
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Well, I think when people think about Secretary of State's office, they're first going to think about elections.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And we do elections well here in our state.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But one of the things I want to improve upon is I want to make sure that when absentee ballots are returned by mail, that becomes a state law.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Signatures are checked on that outer envelope.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Currently, it's a best practice by election authorities across the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But if for some reason someone is choosing not to do that because they're trying to change the outcome of an election, we need to make sure that we have the law in place so they can be held accountable for that.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Currently, that is not in place.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: I also really want to do a lot more in-depth work to make sure we have bipartisan election judges across the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: It's very hard.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: in our more urban, denser areas of the state to find Republicans to serve as election judges.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And in the rural areas, it's a lot harder to find Democrats to serve as election judges.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And after 10 years of serving as county clerk here in the chief election authority of Green County, you understand well the importance of making sure that not only elections are open and transparent, but you have that bipartisanship, the check and balance there to keep the integrity of the elections secure and intact.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And right now, that's difficult to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so in 2022, when the election integrity bill was passed, I was president of our statewide county clerk association at the time, Marshall.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And at that time, I, as a county clerk of someone in Greene County, wanted to go to another county to be an election judge.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: I had to give them permission to be able to do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Well, we got that barrier removed in the election integrity bill in 2022.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so now if you serve, if you're in another county, you want to go serve in an adjoining county or county clerk.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: to you, you can go do that without the election authority having to give you permission.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So as Secretary of State, I want to be able to pick up that phone and be able to call our state party chairs and say, where do we have an area where we need more Republicans or where do we have an area where we need more Democrats and really work with the kind of chairs to be able to achieve that goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So that's one of the areas I want to work on elections.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Voter registration, keeping the voter registration roster, the roles clean is critically important.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: There's some changes we can do within the office to make the program that we use now, Missouri Central Voter Registration Program, more user-friendly, not only for election authorities, but also for the public to gain access to information when it comes to elections, turnout, and some of the things voters are interested in in terms of learning what happened for past elections.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So that would be very helpful, be able to change that and be able to continue to improve on keeping our voter registration rules clean.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And then the other thing that I think is critically important is business services.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Making sure that anytime someone comes to the Secretary of State's office, especially those who are starting a business for the first time, make sure that not only we help them in terms of getting that license without any undue red tape, but providing them information about financial literacy.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: That's the number one reason new businesses fail is they don't understand financial
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: the nuts and bolts in terms of how to operate that business from a financial perspective.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so if we can provide that information for them, that ability to be able to do that really makes a difference in our communities across the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Because when you're in tough economic times like we are now, small businesses are what keep the bread on the table in terms of your homes across smaller communities and the bigger communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And we need to be able to do that for entrepreneurs and new business owners.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So that's an important goal of mine.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And then it's also...
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: important that we continue to protect our investors that's something that the secretary of state's office does is investment protection and it's really important that we continue to make sure that every time anyone goes to invest their hard-earned dollars they know that it's a safe investment if there's any questions or any concerns the secretary of state's office is there ready to respond and be able to hold anyone accountable who's trying to defraud somebody with any investment that they're investing here in our state
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Election judges.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: What exactly is an election judge?
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Is that an actual public position that someone's elected to or is that a party office or a state position that the secretary of state appoints?
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Just what are election judges?
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Yeah, I tell my friends, if I'm an election judge, you just don't get the robe.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And what that means is that when you think of poll workers, our state statutes calls them election judges.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So they're the people, when you go into your polling location, they're going to greet you, they're going to ask for your name, your ID, and they're going to make sure that you get the correct ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So they are there to watch everything that happens inside a polling location on the day of the election.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And they're bipartisan for a purpose because you want to make sure that there's nothing taking place in that polling location that would potentially throw the outcome of an election because someone is trying to do something that is fraudulent.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so that's why they're there to hold each other accountable, make sure that everyone that's coming in is receiving one ballot, voting that ballot, and then casting that ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so that's the role of election judges across our state.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so when you're not achieving that bipartisanship,
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: people can begin to question the integrity of an election if there's any questions afterward.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: It's a lot easier for people to have faith and confidence when they know that bipartisanship has been achieved.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And I've seen that here in Greene County in terms of we've got
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: A really great candidate in terms of we have a number of Republicans, but we also have a number of Democrats.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so they work together, but they're also there to hold each other accountable.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And that's when you have the best checks and balances in terms of election integrity is when you have that bipartisanship achieved.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: You're listening to Show Me Today.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: This is Marshall Griffin.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: We're speaking with Shane Schoeller.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: He's the county clerk for Greene County.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: He's also a former member of the Missouri House, former House Speaker Roe Tim.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: He's running for Secretary of State and actually ran for Secretary of State in 2012 as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Now, let me ask this.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: One of the candidates that
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: that we interviewed earlier brought up making sure that we only use paper ballots and that we and that they not be connected to any type of database with access to the internet as a measure of security what are your thoughts on how to best secure election results
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Well, I've always been a firm believer in paper ballot because you always want a paper trail.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: For example, the election equipment we have here in Greene County, we went to purchase that in late 2017, early 2018.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: I had a community, I've worked with our community in terms of a panel that came together to be able to experience the election equipment before we purchased it.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But one of the key things that I focused in on was making sure there was no connectivity to the internet.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And so that is a critical priority for any election official to make sure that cannot happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But as I tell folks, it's not just potentially having the software hacked.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: You can have human error, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: I mean, someone could potentially program the software wrong in terms of reading the ballot coding and have an outcome different than how the voters vote.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But that's why right now, today, we're actually testing our election equipment.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: It's called an accuracy and logic test program.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: We're actually going through testing different variations of how that ballot can be tabulated to make sure it's accurate.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Then after the election, we will do that again, but then we also do no less than 5% of the polling locations.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: We will randomly draw them on the night of the election, and then we will go through, and for this August election, we're going to do a hand count for a statewide race, and again, that's randomly drawn.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: We'll hand count a legislative race, either for Congress and the Zurich General Assembly.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: We'll hand count one for our county, and again, all those are randomly drawn.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: We'll hand count one for...
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: for the judiciary race as well, if you have any judiciary selections on your ballot, and then we hand count one for an issue as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: All those are randomly drawn, they're hand counted by bipartisan teams, and then they're compared to what the,
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: information on the night of the election in terms of tabulation from that machine, we compare that tape that printed to the hand count to make sure that that machine was accurately tabulating.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And for some people who believe that hand counting is better than the machines, I try to remind them that, unfortunately, we had a history in our state where hand counting was actually fraudulent.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: It was highly susceptible to fraud.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Another aspect of the Secretary of State's job is to validate language on ballot measures.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: And there's been a bit of a history of past and even the current Secretary of State being challenged over the language used.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: used for some ballot measures, basically with the sponsor saying, no, you're twisting the language to make sure that voters say no to this.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: What's your position as far as ballot language?
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Do you think that the presenters of the ballot measure should have the language as they present it?
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: I think that we need to take a look at that.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Matter of fact, when I ran for it last time in 2012, I offered a measure that would allow essentially a bipartisan committee come together and work on that language.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Because I think one of the challenges you're always going to have is whoever is the Secretary of State, there's going to be some distrust that is applied to any ballot language that's put forth before the voters.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: I do think the ballot language could be a little bit longer sometimes.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: I think the limit of words really affects that.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But I think we need to come together and see if there's an opportunity to bring Republicans, Democrats and potentially independents together to look at the ballot language and hopefully be able to come up with agreed upon language.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And if not, as we know, there's always the opportunity to go to the court, as we see now, and present that to a judge if you don't disagree.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: But I think there's always going to be some level of distrust there.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: regardless of who's the secretary of state when that ballot language is written so this is an opportunity to have that discussion and see if we can't bring together an effort that hopefully has more people in the room that present their different perspectives in terms of how that ballot language is written and hopefully come together and agree upon language that the voters can see when they vote on the day of the election because currently as you know
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Bowel language is constantly challenged in the courts, and that's a cost to the taxpayers, as you well know.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Anytime a secretary of state has to go defend that language, there's a cost to the taxpayers.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: So that's one potential opportunity solution that I've put forth that I would like to at least have for consideration as we think through important things like bowel language.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: As you know, there's a lot of legislation that's often packed into that 50-word summary.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: And oftentimes that 50-word summary, unfortunately, is just not adequate to be able to encompass all the changes that are in that legislative language that's being voted on by the voters.
